source:
## Project 1:Write a Data Science blog post
    
> In this project, I will be using the Boston AirBnB dataset taken from Kaggle. I will be using this information to predict the revenue of a small rental property in the Boston area. Through this project, I will answer the following questions:

> - What is the expected occupancy rate of a rental property in Boston based on a rental price?
> - What is the Average Daily Rate (expected revenue) of a rental property in the Boston area?
> - Try to determine if a small apartment or a small house is a better option for investment and future rental in the Bostor area. This analysis can be the foundation for a more complex model to prodict rental income for a small investments in the Boston area.

> The initial dataset was taken from the 'listings.csv' file. This file contains 3,585 listed properties with 95 columns with many, many features for each property such as ratings, pictures, prices, and many more.

> In this analysis, I will reduce this dataset to only 14 columns to provide me the necessary information to answer previous questions. I developed this work using a classroom Jupyter notebook.

> After reviewing the entire dataset, I was able to identify the columns that I will be using in my work.

> I will focus my analysis using the following 14 columns only:
> 1) - ID
> 2) - Neighbourhood
> 3) - Zipcode
> 4) - Property type
> 5) - Acommodate
> 6) - Bathrooms
> 7) - Bedrooms
> 8) - Price
> 9) - Security deposit
> 10) - Cleaning fee
> 11) - Availability 30
> 12) - Availability 60
> 13) - Availability 90
> 14) - Availability 365

>Below, I will start dropping unnecessary columns.

source: > vii) The next step is to create and calculate the 'Occupancy Rate' column. This rate will give us an idea of how busy the property is during the month. Ideally, as a rental property owner, we are looking for an Occupancy Rate of around 2. This means that our property rental price is not too low or too high. High Occupancy Rates may be a sign that our prices are too low for the area. Low Occupancy Rates may be a sign that our prices are too high for this city. Too high or too low occupancy rates may translate into revenue loss for a rental property.

> In this section, I will try to see if a linear regression model would help us to predict the rental price of 2 types of properties (houses and apartments) for investor who want to buy small properties in the Boston area.

> Initially, the model will use categorical variables: bathrooms and bedrooms

#Split into explanatory and response variables

X = df_house[['bathrooms','bedrooms']]
y = df_house['price']

X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size = .30, random_state = 42)

lm_model = LinearRegression(normalize = True)
lm_model.fit(X_train, y_train)

def clean_fit_linear_mod(df, response_col, cat_cols, dummy_na, test_size=.3, rand_state=42):
    df = df.dropna(subset=[response_col], axis=0)
    df = df.dropna(how='all', axis=1)
    df = create_dummy_df(df_new2, cat_cols, dummy_na)
    #fill_mean=lambda col:col.fillna(col.mean())
    #df = df.apply(fill_mean, axis=0)
    #X= df.drop(response_col, axis=1)
    #y= df[response_col]
    
    #Split into train and test variables
    X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(X, y, test_size = test_size, random_state = rand_state)

    lm_model = LinearRegression(normalize = True) #Instantiate
    lm_model.fit(X_train, y_train) #Fit
    
    y_test_preds = lm_model.predict(X_test)
    y_train_preds = lm_model.predict(X_train)
    
    test_score = r2_score(y_test, y_test_preds)
    train_score = r2_score(y_train, y_train_preds)
    
    return test_score, train_score, lm_model, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test
test_score, train_score, lm_model, X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = clean_fit_linear_mod(df_new, 'price', cat_cols_lst, dummy_na=False)
